Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2013 03:24PM ldesim wrote: Hi, I'm keeping my fingers crossed for you that you keep your eyelashes & brows :)  Congrats on ending your chemo soon!  That's such a fantastic feeling to have it behind you... I hope you celebrate a bit.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2013 10:16AM ldesim wrote: Hi Peggy, You described exactly how I've been reacting, good luck to you.. we can all do this! I've been finding myself going to extremes both with shopping and preparation, you'd think I was going to Siberia alone for a year the way I am acting.. lol  Argynnis, the best to you as well... we're having similar procedures, I hope you're not right handed like me... I think I'm going to struggle with that! Bogogirl, don't be silly, of course your can and there is no such thing as "only" when it comes to surgery.  I hope everything goes well, and you can finish up the rest shortly.. this waiting business is for the birds! Hoping for fast recoveries for everybody.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 01:57PM ldesim wrote: Hi Softballaholic.  I know how you are feeling about being rushed.  My surgery was initially scheduled for the 17th and my oncologist, not liking that.. put up a fuss.  When the woman called me to reschedule, I hyperventilated.. it was awful, I couldn't even finish the telephone call.. I felt totally rushed, I had already mentally psyched myself up for the 17th.  I slept on it and when that poor woman called me back the next day, after apologizing profusely, I agreed to the earlier date. Now I'm wishing I had done it last week, which is what they wanted, because I'd be a week along in the healing process lol. I don't know what your diagnosis is but I know how scary it is to be diagnosed with cancer having lost loved one.  I have watched both my grandfather's, a girlfriend, my best friends husband and my husband's friend all die of cancer, and never for a minute wondered if all this was worth it.  I believe it is and we are very fortunate to have the technology we do now and the treatments and knowledge that we do now to beat this.  I am Her2+ and if I am not mistaken this was at one point a very bad diagnosis to have, and from what my onc told me, this is now the type that responds fantastically to the treatments. Take one day at a time, I know it's hard because I have to reign myself in all the time, but just get yourself through the surgery and then put your mind to the next task and so on and so on. We are all wonderful that is true and that includes you!
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2013 03:08PM ldesim wrote: Hi Cheri, sounds like you're going to have a busy day.  The day after me, best of luck to you.. I hope to hear how you make out.  I've been strangely calm with just a couple of moments of total panic, I'm sure it will get worse as the time draws near.  I feel like I have so much to get in order before surgery and I suppose that  is keeping the nerves at bay for now.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 06:03AM ldesim wrote: Hi Italflamingo... I have surgery tomorrow and so far am coping better than I thought, I have small moments of panic, but for the most part am pretty calm.  I think I'm at the point that I just want this over with.. to me its a step closer to getting my normal life back, if there even is such a thing after this!!! I've already had my full course of chemo, I did read some posts of others who had chemo, surgery and them more chemo.. I wish I remembered what the thread was.. sorry.  I will have radiation starting shortly, I think they said 3 weeks after surgery, another hurdle to get over. How are you doing with the chemo and do you have a surgery date yet?
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2013 05:06PM ldesim wrote: Bobogirl, you crack me up!  I kept threatening my co-workers that when my hair grew in long enough I was gonna spike it and dye if Fushia. Ashleigh, I guess we have no choice but to get used to whatever, that is what this whole process has taught me lol.  It does not surprise me that it it will last some time, that's just par for the course haha.  I don't know which I hate more, the electric shocks or that creepy feeling when you touch the area.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 02:10PM ldesim wrote: No, she checked on them when I went in for the drains yesterday.. she said she would call me.  I assumed I'd get that info over the phone, is that now how they do it?  Now I'm gonna panic if she asks me to come in.  Last time I had to go in for test results it was for the biopsy and the news was not good! I would hope they would call you if they weren't ready.. that would just be too cruel! Good luck!!!! I'll be thinking about you, I hope all goes well! Ashleigh, I'm not sure my place of work (law offiice) would agree with that haha.
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2013 06:13PM ldesim wrote: Hi Barbhenz, There are just some days we just can't manage to be positive and that's ok.  What did the plastic surgeon say about the chest soreness? Somebody else was complaining about ths too.. I can't recall what forum it was, nor do I remember anybody havig any words of wisdom about it.. sorry :( I didn't have expanders and that does seem to slow down the healing process from what I've read of others experiences... I sure do hope you feel better soon and you get a good report tomorrow.  I'm sorry that you're going through this a second time.. that is just horrible :(
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: ldesim wrote: Hi all,  I've been lurking around for a couple of days and want to thank all you wonderful ladies (and the men as well!) for sharing your experiences, for giving comfort and providing laughter.  Reading through these posts have made this entire experience seem much less scary.  I've learned so much here which has calmed me down.  I'm the type that when I'm at the doctor's I seem to zone out and just don't absorb any of the information! I've just been scheduled for my mastectomy on April 9th at Brigham/Dana and will not be having reconstruction immediately, if ever... I have not decided yet! I've already finished my chemo regimen, hopefully for good and knock on wood, was one of the lucky ones that had little side effects and I managed to continue working full time. The surgery for me is the biggest hurdle, well actually not the surgery, but the recovery... I think I'm going to struggle with that.  I can't help feeling that since I've been lucky through the chemo, the shoe will drop during recovery.  I think I'm going to be fine with the loss of the breast to a certain extent, but who knows once I am faced with the loss.  I will admit that I am dreading facing the summer when I won't be used to being.. what's the term you guys have been using.. uniboobed? :)  But thinking back, I didn't think I'd recover from losing my hair and it turns out it wasn't bad at all and what's more I actually enjoy wearing a wig and love the fact I don't have to deal with trying to get my probem hair to look decent in the morning!!!  Now the eyelashes and eyebrows.. that annoys the crap out of me, especially since I didn't totally lose those until my 2nd to last chemo.. I really did think I was going to escape that one.. silly me.. lol. Who else is taking the big plunge with me in April? Dx 9/28/2012, IDC, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 12/6/2012 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Surgery 4/9/2013 Lymph node removal: Right; Mastectomy: Right Hormonal Therapy 5/6/2013 Radiation Therapy 5/15/2013 Breast, Lymph nodes Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2013 09:44AM ldesim wrote: Glad to hear from you Bobogirl! Yep surgery yesterday, got home a litte while ago.. have been up and around since yesterday afternoon.  A little soreness, feels more like I just overdid a workout in my armpit and just a dull ache where the breat was... I feel fantastic considering, so far no actual pain.  BS was awesome, held my hand while I was getting pain block.. camet o my room and sat down and talked to me.  I had a gorgeous private room, which I hadn't expected and loved the room service whenever the mood struck.  It was like a mini vactaion! Hope everybody else is recovering easily.. and for those of you with surgeries coming up... The anticipation is worse than the actual event, I am so glad to get it over with and I exected to be way more uncomfortable than I am.  I have two drains and so far they are not a problem either.  So try to stay calm!!! Get the patch for nausea before surgery and if they offer you a block.. get it... I had not once ounce of pain in my first 24 hours and I didn't have to get myself groggy from pain meds. Nor did I need a breathing tube during surgery. Hugs to everybody.. we can do this!!!
Posts.Title: April 2013 Mastectomy ldesim ashleigh

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 08:33AM ldesim wrote: lol wth.. black eye?? Why did they tape your eyes shut that sounds horrible!  You should get a photo of that, because it is something to laugh about in the future.  Its similar I guess to an epidural...  they inject the vertabrae in your neck and it lasts for 15-20 hours. Talk to the anesthesiologist about it.. I also had the patch because I get motion sickness and didn't want to chance getting nauseous.  I got a tad woozy my first attempt out of bed, but that was the worst of it.. knock on wood. omg.. that's horrible about your reaction to the pain meds, hopefully they can find something that works this time.  I am allergic to coedine and they gave me Oxycodone which did its job lol. Hope you hear soon when you can get yours over with!  I am so glad have this behind me.

I just felt off.. not myself, but nothing I could point a finger at. Upset stomach, which it seemed happened if I let if get empty... lethargy..  I tossed it up to the Neulasta shots as this feeling seemed to hit me after having that.  Kobrien I am so sorry about your son.  Congrats on your new marriage.  Every phase of BC has brought untold terror to me.. but then it has always turned out to be not as bad as I thought it would be, and in fact, I feel silly sometimes for having been so afraid. You'll get through this as you've gotten through everything so far.. and we're all here for you as best  we can be!

Posts.Content: May 18, 2013 05:14AM ldesim wrote: Melody, I started Tamoxifen almost 2 weeks ago and I was terrified to start.  So far I have not experienced side effects.. in another thread I was informed that they take a long time to kick in.. so you should be ok through your treatments... at least I hope you will be! Actually the tanks I have been wearing are hubby's old Fruit of the Loom white tanks that shrunk in the wash and he passes on to me lol. They are rather thin from lots of washings and probably because they are underwear.  They are  not as bulky as I thought they would be and it is undetectable under clothing.  This way I can have the Aqua on 24/7.

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2013 10:25PM ldesim wrote: Radiation is so much easier than chemo, you will see.  The biggest pain is the daily aspect of it, but even that you get used to.  I don't feel I get to know my caregivers as well as with chemo, but that is because even though you are there daily, you are in and out in 15 mins most days. My place has  a comfy waiting room, there is always a puzzle going on or somebody to chat with.. I have met some wonderful people.  There is coffee you can brew and a fridge full of juices and water and a big basket of snacks. You'll see.. don't even waste one minute worrying about it.. but I'm sure you will anyways... best of luck to you tomorrow.. you'll be fine!!! Honest!

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2013 11:37PM ldesim wrote: I can't believe I am facing my last treatment tomorrow... for anybody just starting, it sounds like forever, but it goes by relatively quickly.  The worst week for me was the 5th, I had on and off fatigue and skin discomfort.  Since I've been on the boosts the discomfort has eased up considerably.  The really bad area under my armpit is now peeling and there is new soft skin underneath.  I have been able to wear a bra throughout by wearing a cotton t shirt underneath, plus I could keep the Aquaphor or the radiation cream on 24/7 by doing this without ruining my bra or other clothing.  Needless to say the T-shirts will be chucked very soon :) Soteria, I found the boots to be easier than the regular radiation as it was a smaller area that targeted the incision site.. so maybe the skin is tougher there? I have no trouble at all in that area, only the slightest pink. Michele, laughing over the tossing in the air of the wig.   Lin, your hair must grow fast!! I'm 4 months out and it is still so short... it's getting thicker, but way too short :(  IamNancy, I won't go wigless either.. but as far as the slipping, I haven't had a problem when I wear a nylon cap over my hair. TMM60, hopefully the fatigue phase passes you by quickly... that to me was the worst SE of all. Melody that is awful what you overheard.. how dare they.. you would think people would have compassion, not make nasty comments.. I wish you had just whipped your wig onto their table. Heart, I am sorry you are having such issues, you seem to have had the worst time of this phase and I can only hope that you heal fast :( Iamnancy, just read about your extended treatment.. I am sick for you, to find out you had an additional week must have been devastating *hugs* I am so sad to hear about the pain and skin issues some of you have been dealing with, I can only hope that the healing is quick and this all becomes a bad memory. {{{{gentle hugs}}}}
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2013 09:24PM ldesim wrote: 2 days of no radiation and I feel so free! lol.  It's peeling like crazy and yes there is a smell.  My RO told me the best thing for healing was to leave it alone and let air at it.  She gave me something to spray on it a few mins before showering that will help dislodge some of the dead skin but told me that putting lotion and stuff on may dislodge the skin before it is ready to come off, which I did in a couple of spots and it was raw and painful. They gave me some medicated gauze like strips and I've just been using those under a form fitting camisole. Carol, you'll be fine, I bet you never thought you could get through everything you've been through so far and you did it. Hope everybody has a nice releaxing, healing weekend.

Its another scary stop on what has been a nightmare ride, but for me hopefully I will arrive at my cancer free destination!

Posts.Content: May 15, 2013 01:53AM ldesim wrote: IamNancy.. congrats on getting your first one over with...big hugs....  I was dragged in twice now just to have done what you got done today and I don't get my first radiation until tomorrow.  The whole time I was laying there today, I was thinking what a waste.. I could have already had a treatment over with :(  Thanks for sharing your experience.. hahah.. my arms were falling asleep today .. I wiggled my fingers off and on to keep feeling in them, it's hard staying in one position for so long! Lin43.. good luck tomorrow, I will be thinking about you too.. we got this!! Big Hugs!  I feel the same way, I am scared, but I just want to get it over with as well.  I'm sorry to hear you are having trouble with the Herceptin, I hope the Turmeric works out for you and I second your motion of a quick and uneventful six weeks.  Hubby got me this Crystal deodorant stuff.. not sure if it works so great yet.. I'll let you guys know.
Posts.Title: Summer 2013 Rads Wildlyshel sandiesau

Posts.Content: May 16, 2013 02:51AM ldesim wrote: Lin43, we did it! 1 down!  I don't know what the bolus is, but they put a towel wrap on me which I'll get every other day to bring it to the skin surface.  I'm a little sore in my armpit, but no redness... they gave me Eucerin Aquaphor to use.   I love the calendar idea.. and it will make her feel good to plan something a nice treat for you as well as give you something to look forward to.  Hubby made me a nice pasta dinner and I treated myself to some cadbury :) I agree with you, when I start feeling sorry for myself, I remember seeing some women in chemo that were not doing very well at all and I've also read stories on these boards and I know things can be so much worse and if they told me that I had to do this for 5 months, then I would in the hopes I would never get to the point where it could be so much worse. IamNancy, I asked my RO today if I could put deodorant on after treatment when I start on mornings next week and she hesitated and said no, that the area would be too sensitive.. I don't know what the heck I am going to do... I was sweating at work today and while I didn't smell anything.. I am still totally self concious about it and can't imagine 6 weeks of this... not to mention my clothes are going to stain I am sure.. sigh... I haven't tried the Crystal spray yet, I ordered it from Amazon, I also ordered EO organic spray.  Hubby uses the Crystal solid, but I don't like it at all.  Be careful with Tom's not all of them as natural as they suggest from the bit of reading I did on them. I read somewhere just plain baking soda made into a paste, but that sounds so unpleasant. Tinkerbellzcharm, welcome.. you'll get a lot of wonderful information here.  Congrats on finishing chemo!  I am not a candidate for recon at this time, so I don't have much input as I haven't thought about it much yet. Slv, thanks for the recommondation, Sephora usually had great products, but they are pricey.  2 hours is a long commute daily, I hope you can do an alternative treatment and make it easier on you. Heart, good news on the leg!!  Sounds like you're in good hands and I bet concentrating on the breathing will keep you occupied during the process.. it sounds interesting. Well ladies, enough for me today, I am going to get some rest... have a good evening :)

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2013 02:39PM ldesim wrote: Slv.. my hair grew back the same way.. the sides and back were coming in and very little on the top.    I too feared it was not going to come in.   That was not the case, it just appears to be slower for some reason.  I finished end of Feb and have about 1 1/2 inches back and sides and about 3/4 inch on top!  As far as eyelashes, eyebrows.. Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2013 04:46PM ldesim wrote: Congrats ALCS97!!!!! WooHoo!! I don't recall any nausea during rads.. just fatigue for a small period of time. Lenn13ka, I am at Dana Farber too.. or I should say.. I'm done doing my rads at Dana ;) I can say there is nothing so nice as waking up the day after your last rad treatment and knowing you don't have to go in!! Gowiththeflow, love your attitude!  Good to see you Lin43, so glad to hear you are on the mend!  I am actually glad I am getting the Herception (I go every 3 weeks) because at least I feel I am still doing something.. Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2013 03:13AM ldesim wrote: This is what is getting me through hair loss 1) a great wig that I bought the first day of chemo, 2) a nice soft jersey knit sleep cap that I got from headcovers.com (has elastic on back so it doesn't come off head at night.); and 3) newsboy type hat that I wear over a crochet skull cap around the house (skull cap covers more of neck and side of head, helps keep newscap cap on and provides warmth, while newsboy caps brim makes me feel less naked and in my opinion less like a cancer patient. I didn't like the look of just skull caps or turbans or scarves... to me I just felt that I looked like the sickly cancer patient that I was. I fought until the bitter end as I couldn't bear to lose my hair even one day sooner than necessary.  It started tingling/itching on a Monday, continued to Tuesday, starting coming out in clumps in the shower on Wednesday, same on Thursday.. 2nd chemo, hair in pony tail through Friday.. Sat morning shower and the tub and shower are covered in hair, had a good cry, cleaned up the mess (what a major pain), asked hubby for the clippers and shaved my head and cried some more.  Wore wig around the house Sunday to get used to it... wore it to work on Monday and cried every time a cowoer complimented my hair lol. 6 months later and my hair is starting to grow back and I'm still not over losing my hair! If I had it to do again,
Posts.Title: April 2013 Chemo Group BeHereNow 6cats

Sydneyluv, I don't know what I'd do without these forums.. they have been so helpful to me and it's so nice to chat with others that understand exactly what you are going through.  Thank you for explanation.. that is really fascinating, and how great that you'll be done so quickly. Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2013 04:18PM ldesim wrote: HALFWAY POINT.... woooohoooo!!!!  Big hugs Lin43!!!!  I'm so glad you have your daughter there for you, she sounds wonderful :)  I have the problem with holding still when a good song comes on, they always have music playing in the room during treatment and sometimes I just forget LOL I'm doing great so far, I'm tired towards the end of the day, but my job is demanding as well, so i could be a combination of things.  I have a little redness, but nothing too bad.. so far so good. Welcome to the new faces, you're all going to do just fine!! Like any of the stages of this horrible journey, its the unknown that gets us so worked up!!  We can be our own worst enemies, or at least I know I can be.   Soteria, I hope you got good news with your results!  I had consultation, tattoos & xrays in 1 visit a couple of weeks before treatment started and then a "run through" the day before treatment started.  The first visit was under 2 hours and the run through was about 1/2 hour.
